author: By Benjamin P. Russell
title: An Author Wrote About Her Sister’s Murder. It Led to a Breakthrough.
description: Cristina Rivera Garza wanted to shed light on the life of her sister, killed 30 years ago. Her book, part of a larger call for justice by women in Mexico, helped locate the suspect.
content: It took Cristina Rivera Garza 30 years to write the story of her sister’s unsolved murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: West Point Cadets Overdose During Spring Break in Florida, Officials Say
description: The cadets, along with another young man, were exposed to what is believed to be cocaine laced with fentanyl, and two were on ventilators late Friday, officials said.
content: Several West Point cadets were among six young men on spring break who overdosed this week on what was believed to be cocaine laced with fentanyl at a rental home in Wilton Manors, Fla., officials said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Afghan Embassy, Now Out of Money, Will Shut Down, U.S. Says
description: The development caps a sad saga for Afghan diplomats, who have 30 days to apply to remain in the United States or face the threat of deportation.
content: WASHINGTON — Without the backing of a recognized government or money to keep the lights on, Afghanistan’s embassy to the United States is shutting down, State Department officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha and Elizabeth Bristow
title: Paris Fashion Week: Standing Out in the Crowds
description: A photographer’s sidewalk view outside the shows.
content: There’s just nothing like photographing people in Paris, but over the past two years the scene has changed and evolved as the fashion shows stumbled along through each pandemic wave. Now, the streets are full again. Camera technology allows novices to take exceptional photos. Most notably, the level of style from fans outside the shows has been so elevated, it would be foolish for the photographers who usually train their lenses on fashion editors and influencers who wear heritage brands to ignore them. It brings a renewed excitement, reminiscent of the old days when someone might be discovered shopping at a mall — a thrill like the kind one experiences when unearthing a gem at a thrift store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Street battles hit a Kyiv suburb, some of the closest fighting to the capital yet.
description: The capture of the once affluent suburb of Irpin would potentially help Moscow encircle the nearby capital, military analysts say.
content: IRPIN, Ukraine — In Irpin, just outside the capital city of Kyiv, Ukrainian and Russian soldiers were fighting a street-by-street battle on Saturday, turning what was a leafy suburb just two weeks ago into a suburban battleground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Hundreds of Planes Are Stranded in Russia. They May Never Be Recovered.
description: Western companies that own the planes face little prospect of getting them back, meaning billions of dollars in losses.
content: Hope has faded quickly for a handful of Western companies eager to recover planes leased to airlines in Russia, with the authorities there intent on keeping foreign-registered aircraft within the country and President Vladimir V. Putin openly discussing nationalizing the assets of foreign businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: M.L.B. Nears Deal With Another Streaming Service to Carry Some Games Exclusively
description: Peacock would join Apple TV+, which has already reached an agreement that will make it harder for cable subscribers to find major-league games.
content: Ready to watch Major League Baseball before lunch? That will be an option if NBCUniversal completes a deal with the league to carry 18 games on its Peacock streaming service, some starting as early as 11:30 a.m. Eastern time and others just after noon, a person with knowledge of the deal said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: He Spent Decades Protecting Buffalo. A Microscopic Invader Threatens That Work.
description: Fred DuBray’s bison herd in South Dakota has been ravaged by Mycoplasma bovis, a bacteria that has decimated herds across the Plains and the West.
content: BLACKFOOT, S.D. — On the ice-glazed banks of the Missouri River, coyotes chewed through the hide of a buffalo that had recently died from disease. In a corral up the hill, more than 20 orphaned buffalo calves crowded together in the cold with no mother to protect them. Down in the pasture, a few animals stood apart from the others, coughing violently, clouds of their breath hanging in the winter air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: House Democrats Push Biden to Build a Better Midterm Message
description: House Democrats have been pressing the president to come up with a bumper-sticker-worthy slogan. The White House says it’s sharpening its message.
content: WASHINGTON — After offering her customary lavish praise of President Biden, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi got to the business at hand at a White House meeting last month on the midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: The Comfort of Sports During Difficult Times
description: Don’t feel guilty about seeking relief by in a game.
content: As I sit writing in a quiet part of my apartment building, I can see two televisions. One is playing CNN. Jake Tapper is asking a reporter how victims of the opioid crisis confronted the Sackler family, which owns Purdue Pharma, at a hearing on Thursday. Earlier, the network focused on images from the war in Ukraine — bloodied victims of bombings, bodies buried in mass graves, buildings on fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: How Much Real Money Can You Make From Virtual Art?
description: NFTs are making some collectors and artists rich, but success in this high-risk marketplace is more art than science.
content: Late on a Friday last spring, Izzy Pollak decided to buy two Bored Ape NFTs, which — as a reminder for the many people thinking, Yeah, but I still don’t know what an NFT is — means he bought unique, digital images (in this case, of apes).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Ron Miles, Understated Master of Jazz Cornet, Is Dead at 58
description: He enjoyed the admiration of his fellow musicians for decades, but he had just been starting to find his place in the spotlight.
content: Ron Miles, whose gleaming, generously understated cornet playing made him one of the most rewarding bandleaders in contemporary jazz, if also one of its most easily overlooked, died on Tuesday at his home in Denver. He was 58.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: For Italy’s Sled Hockey Team, ‘This One Means More’
description: A team of part-time players that gets on the ice just twice a week hopes a dramatic win to end its Paralympics run could serve as a building block for the future.
content: BEIJING — There are no medals for fifth place in the Paralympic sled hockey tournament. But judging by the scenes of exultation and joy on the ice at China’s National Indoor Stadium on Friday, the Italian national team will cope just fine without them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: Are We Facing Nuclear War?
description: Answering your questions about the threat of attack.
content: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Republicans Sense an Opportunity in Nevada’s Restless Latino Voters
description: Seizing on signs that suggest Democrats are losing support among Hispanic voters nationwide, Republicans are targeting Senator Catherine Cortez Masto’s seat.
content: When Senator Catherine Cortez Masto and her allies unveiled their first paid ads of the 2022 election cycle, the Nevada Democrat’s intended audience was clear: the state’s quarter-of-a-million Latino voters, a critical swing vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simone Tagliapietra, Georg Zachmann and Morgan Bazilian
title: How to Wean Europe Off Russian Gas as Swiftly as Possible
description: A trans-Atlantic energy pact would counter Russia’s might.
content: Russia’s unprovoked invasion of Ukraine has pressed Europe to fundamentally rethink how it keeps its lights on and its industries powered. Steps that would have sounded crazy only a few weeks ago — burning more coal or scaling-up government intervention in energy markets — are now urgently needed to stop financing Vladimir Putin’s war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Lynsey Addario
title: In a Kyiv Basement, 19 Surrogate Babies Are Trapped by War but Kept Alive by Nannies
description: Some surrogate mothers are trapped by the fighting as their due dates near. And newborns face uncertain fates, with many biological parents now unable to travel to Ukraine.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Down a dusty stairwell, hidden from the shelling that has become the grim background noise of Ukraine’s capital, Ludmila Yashenko fusses with the babies. There are 19 of them, sleeping or cooing in neatly arranged cribs, fed regularly from tubs of baby formula.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Yarn, Introspection and Pancakes
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
content: Hello, readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Meet the Underdog of Senior Care
description: The Program of All-Inclusive Care for the Elderly, funded by Medicare and Medicaid, has quietly succeeded in enabling some older Americans to age in place.
content: Felicia Biteranta was struggling when, five years ago, she enrolled in a PACE program operated by Lutheran Senior Life in Jersey City, N.J.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: France Cares About Green Causes, but Not Its Green Party
description: As a presidential election looms, the Greens lag far behind in the polls. Analysts say the party has failed to inspire voters and show them it can rule.
content: MONTPELLIER, France — Yannick Jadot, the candidate for the French Green Party in April’s presidential elections, walked through a small cheering crowd to a podium topped with banners featuring his face, as speakers blasted a version of “What a Wonderful World” by the punk rock singer Joey Ramone. The candidate bobbed his head to the rhythm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: First Comes Marriage, Then Comes Love
description: In these new romance novels, weddings aren’t bows tied on at the finish — they’re the starting point.
content: “Marriage isn’t a word — it’s a sentence.” That famous quip is especially true in romance novels, where marriage is often a starting point rather than an end goal. This month we look at three new romances in which a wedding is not a bow tied on at the finish, but a tether pulling characters through the plot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Parents, What Would Make Your Lives Better?
description: Two years into the pandemic, what still needs fixing?
content: On this day two years ago, I remember gripping my younger daughter’s hand especially tight on the way to her preschool. We were almost at the front door when I felt my phone buzz with an email from the school: A parent in the community had been exposed to the coronavirus, and “out of an abundance of caution we recommend that you keep your child home if possible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Neil MacFarquhar
title: The Russians Might Have Expected a Warm Welcome. Instead the Mayor Labeled Them ‘Occupiers.’
description: The 33-year-old mayor of Melitopol, Ivan Fyodorov, encouraged defiance. Then he was arrested, and hasn’t been heard from since.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Ivan Fyodorov, as his name suggests, is an ethnic Russian in a southern Ukrainian city where Russian is commonly spoken and where cultural and familial ties to the motherland run deep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Donald Pinkel, Who Developed a Cure for Childhood Leukemia, Dies at 95
description: The disease was once a virtual death sentence for children. Today, his aggressive treatments mean that almost everyone survives it.
content: Dr. Donald Pinkel, a pediatrician who, starting in the early 1960s, developed an aggressive treatment for childhood leukemia that transformed the disease from a virtual death sentence to one that almost every patient survives, died on Wednesday at his home in San Luis Obispo, Calif. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Until recently it was the ‘stealth’ Omicron: Here’s what we know about the BA.2 variant.
description: As the Omicron coronavirus surge subsides, researchers are keeping an eye on a highly transmissible subvariant known as BA.2. Although it doesn’t appear to have the capacity to drive a large new wave of infections, the variant could potentially slow the current decline of Covid cases and make treatments more difficult.
content: As the Omicron coronavirus surge subsides, researchers are keeping an eye on a highly transmissible subvariant known as BA.2. Although it doesn’t appear to have the capacity to drive a large new wave of infections, the variant could potentially slow the current decline of Covid cases and make treatments more difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: The Pros and Cons of Buying a Tenant-Occupied Apartment
description: With a renter already in place, the home could come at a lower price and generate income. But the potential pitfalls may cost more in the long run.
content: Q: We are considering buying a tenant-occupied apartment in a condo. The tenant has lived there since August 2019, and the market-rate lease will expire in four months. The seller’s agent said they could deliver the apartment vacant, but that we’d have more leverage on the sale price if we kept the tenant. We visited the apartment and the tenant has kept everything clean and in good shape. We’re not in a rush to occupy the apartment and it would be nice to have some income in the interim. What are the pitfalls we should be aware of before we make this decision?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: Booster shot data from New York City shows major disparities by race and neighborhood.
description: The data showed that only about 36 percent of city residents had received a booster shot, and the numbers varied significantly by neighborhood and race.
content: Much like the rest of the country, New York City has struggled to convince some groups of residents to get a booster shot of the coronavirus vaccine. But new data released by the city on Wednesday shows wide disparities among who in the city is getting a third dose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Bringing Outsider Artists In
description: Summertime Gallery is redefining what outsider means, one art show at a time.
content: Sophia Cosmadopoulos and Anna Schechter, who run Summertime Gallery in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, don’t write the press materials for their exhibitions. And when the women organize a show, they exercise little influence over the artwork on display, or even how the gallery looks. They are, by design, hands-off gallerists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang W. Lee and David Waldstein
title: How Ukrainian Paralympians Pushed Through Fear and Worry
description: By day in Beijing, athletes raced and trained. By night, they spent time on their phones, connecting with loved ones under attack back home in Ukraine.
content: BEIJING — With heavy hearts and unimaginable worry, athletes from the Ukrainian national Paralympic team arrived in China two weeks ago, seeking to win medals and draw attention to the plight of their country through their athletic achievement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kisselgoff
title: Yuriko, Keeper of Martha Graham’s Flame, Is Dead at 102
description: A choreographer and dancer, she was associated with Graham for more than 50 years, and founded and directed the Martha Graham Ensemble, a student company.
content: Yuriko Kikuchi, who under the single name Yuriko was a leading dancer in Martha Graham’s company from the 1940s to 1967 and then a keeper of Graham’s flame through her demanding teaching and outstanding revivals of early Graham works, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 102.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Maluma, Fashion Chameleon
description: The international pop star expands his empire.
content: A few days after a January snowstorm, Juan Luis Londoño Arias, the 28-year-old Colombian pop star who performs as Maluma, entered a Midtown Manhattan office building near the Macy’s flagship store. Wearing a tie-dyed, periwinkle, denim jacket and pants, he’d somehow managed to keep his chunky-soled white leather Prada boots pristine, despite the rivers of slush on the sidewalks. Like magic, shortly after he showed up, the sun broke through the overcast sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick, Nadav Gavrielov and Zachary Small
title: MoMA Patron, Denied Entry, Stabs Two Employees
description: The police were still looking for the suspect, who grew enraged upon discovering his membership had been revoked. Both victims were in stable condition.
content: A man who was denied entry to the Museum of Modern Art because his membership had been revoked jumped over the reception desk and stabbed two employees on Saturday afternoon, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Saving Each Other’s Lives, Quite Literally
description: An instinct for detecting health problems, and a healthy appetite for sex, have bonded Brian Gari and Jeanne Cathcart for the last 12 years.
content: Brian Gari has a background in theater, but nothing could prepare him for the drama of his first years of marriage to Jeanne Cathcart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Body Language
description: Christina Iverson and Katie Hale keep us on our toes.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is Christina Iverson and Katie Hale’s second clever Sunday collaboration; they’ve gone from audible to visual wordplay with this grid, whose theme reminds me of a large, organized variety puzzle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Scherzer’s Message as Camp Opens: ‘It’s Over. Let’s Just Play Baseball.’
description: Max Scherzer was a vocal leader during the lockout, but now he is focused on getting ready for the season. He’ll have help after his team traded for yet another All-Star pitcher.
content: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Max Scherzer, the Mets’ new star pitcher, was perhaps the most prominent face of the players’ union’s fight with Major League Baseball’s club owners over a new labor contract.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
title: Ukraine War Ushers In ‘New Era’ for U.S. Abroad
description: President Biden is rethinking relationships with allies as well as rivals — including China, Iran and Venezuela — to counter President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
content: WASHINGTON — The war in Ukraine has prompted the biggest rethinking of American foreign policy since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, infusing the United States with a new sense of mission and changing its strategic calculus with allies and adversaries alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson
title: U.S. to Send Arms to Ukraine, as Russia Intensifies Campaign of Destruction
description: A defiant mayor of a captured city was kidnapped by Russian troops, Ukrainian authorities say, an act that prompted hundreds to protest.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Russian forces stepped up their campaign of bombardments aimed at devastating Ukraine’s cities and towns on Saturday, as the White House announced it was sending an additional $200 million in arms and equipment to help Ukraine, defying Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Ukraine War and the Retro-Future
description: What happens when you layer 19th-century geopolitics on 21st century reality?
content: Long before Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, his aggressions were often met by the accusation — leveled by John Kerry and Angela Merkel, among others — that he’s a 19th-century figure in a 21st-century world. It’s a line that seemed intended to judge Putin guilty not just of wickedness but of anachronism, which is somehow more confounding to the modern mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Bobbie Nelson, Longtime Pianist for Brother Willie, Dies at 91
description: They grew up together playing music, and in 1973 she became a core member of the band that would take Mr. Nelson to worldwide fame.
content: Bobbie Nelson, the longtime piano player in her brother Willie’s band and a grounding influence in his life and music, died on Thursday in Austin, Texas. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liesl Schillinger
title: The Land of the Ice and Snow
description: In “Extreme North,” Bernd Brunner explores the idea of what “the north” means to different cultures — and why.
content: EXTREME NORTH: A Cultural HistoryBy Bernd Brunner Translated by Jefferson Chase
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: One More Census Takeaway: The End of an Era of Counting the Nation?
description: Some experts are arguing that it’s time for the census to aggressively make use of government data and other sources to augment its own decennial count.
content: WASHINGTON — Beyond the reports of undercounts and overcounts in population totals, there is another takeaway from the post-mortem of 2020 census data issued on Thursday: This could be the last census of its kind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Officer Who Killed Ma’Khia Bryant Will Not Face Charges
description: The 16-year-old girl had a turbulent life in Ohio’s foster care system and was swinging a knife at a woman when a police officer fatally shot her last year.
content: A grand jury has voted to bring no charges against the white police officer who shot and killed Ma’Khia Bryant, a 16-year-old Black girl, as she swung a knife at a woman during a raucous dispute last year in the front yard of her foster home in Ohio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Salman Masood
title: India Accidentally Fires a Missile at Pakistan. Calm Ensues.
description: Mistrust runs deep between the nuclear-armed neighbors, but Pakistan had a low-key response to what India called a “technical malfunction.” No casualties were reported.
content: JAIPUR, India — One nuclear-armed state fired a cruise missile at another nuclear-armed state this week. They were not at war, and it did not start one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: McDonald’s Ice Cream Woes Have Inspired Memes, Mockery and Now, a Federal Lawsuit
description: A California tech company that tried to solve the problem of malfunctioning ice cream machines claims in the suit that it was thwarted by McDonald’s.
content: It’s a perennial lament of McDonald’s loyalists: Why are the ice cream machines always down?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: With Bombings and a Funeral, the War Arrives in Ukraine’s West
description: Western Ukraine has been a safe haven for Ukrainian refugees, as well as businessmen, journalists and diplomats. But attacks in two cities pierced the sense of security in the region.
content: LUTSK, Ukraine — Men in camouflage, hardened by battle, sniffled as a Ukrainian Orthodox choir sang the haunting funeral mass. One man put his arm around another as tears welled in his eyes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Russian Scientists Face Isolation Following Invasion of Ukraine
description: International collaborations are unraveling as researchers, including many in Russia, speak out against the invasion of Ukraine.
content: One of the glories of international scientific collaborations, besides sharing costs and brainpower, is the building of personal relationships that transcend individual cultures, traditions and political regimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Mentally Worn Out
description: Natan Last’s Saturday puzzle will have you dancing in the street.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — It has been more than three and a half years since we’ve solved a Natan Last puzzle on a Saturday, which is far too long. This constructor is deservedly a favorite among solvers, and this puzzle shouldn’t disappoint — a lot of nimble wordplay, interesting trivia and not a single dud or misstep that I can see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Hamblin
title: Can Public Health Be Saved?
description: Americans’ trust in health insitutions is declining. Here’s how to get it back.
content: This article is part of Times Opinion’s reflection on the two-year mark of the Covid pandemic. Read more in a note from Alexandra Sifferlin, Opinion’s health and science editor, in our Opinion Today newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Reiss and Denise Lu
title: Bilingual Signs Are Disappearing in Chinatown. We Investigated.
description: To document a fading street-sign program in New York City, three journalists had to put on their walking shoes.
content: Aaron Reiss, a freelance multimedia journalist covering immigrant communities in New York City, and Denise Lu, a graphics editor at The Times, teamed up for an article that examines bilingual signs in Manhattan’s Chinatown. Together, they shared how the article came together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: That Russian Business You’re Boycotting Isn’t Actually Russian
description: The consumer activism that makes a vodka C.E.O. say: ‘Do you know we’re Latvian?’
content: They poured the liquid out — blueberry-flavored, orange-flavored and the original, face-puckering unflavored version — tweeting #DumpRussianVodka and, at gay bars across the country, made do with Absolut and soda instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: L.S.U. Men’s Basketball Coach Fired After N.C.A.A. Alleges Violations
description: Will Wade was accused by N.C.A.A. regulators of offering cash and jobs to lure recruits.
content: Louisiana State abruptly fired men’s basketball coach Will Wade on Saturday, less than a week after the school received a notice of allegations from the N.C.A.A. that accused Wade of five major rules violations, including making cash payments and job offers to help lure a recruit to the school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams and Tania Ganguli
title: Brittney Griner’s Circle Turns to a Common Strategy: Silence
description: Those close to Griner have said little publicly since the W.N.B.A. star was detained in Russia on Feb. 17 on drug charges. Their approach has parallels with other efforts to release Americans held overseas.
content: The detention of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner in Russia on drug charges has left her supporters searching for a road map to a resolution in what could be an especially dangerous situation during the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Adam Dean
title: On Pacific Islands Covid Once Spared, an Outbreak Accentuates Inequality
description: New Caledonia escaped the coronavirus for a year and a half, but a surge in cases has led to a state of emergency, with the disease disproportionately hurting the French territory’s Indigenous people.
content: NOUMÉA, New Caledonia — Festooned with hibiscus flowers and woven palm fronds, scores of guests gathered for a celebration during New Caledonia’s wedding season. The aroma of grilled fish and yams bathed in coconut milk wafted over the revelers on the island of Lifou, population 10,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy and Ashley Wong
title: After 2 Years of Pandemic Life, Turn Toward Normalcy Is a Shake-Up
description: As the Omicron variant recedes, cities and states with the longest mask and vaccine mandates are rapidly lifting them. The abrupt shift has unsettled the most vigilant Americans.
content: It was two years ago that the World Health Organization declared Covid-19 a pandemic, and after nearly one million deaths across the United States, the virus is far from gone. Rates of new infections, while improving, are still higher now than the beginning of last summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Arctic Security Concerns Resurface in Canada’s Territories Amid Russian War
description: Between melting sea ice and increased militarization, the Arctic is changing, and premiers in Canada’s territories say the Russian war is another reason to put Arctic security on the policy forefront.
content: For the better part of next week, residents in Canada’s Northwest Territories may see a greater military presence and aircraft whirring about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Zelensky Answers Hamlet
description: The Ukrainian president addresses the existential question for the world.
content: WASHINGTON — For actors, it is the most gripping, feared line ever written.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Pawel
title: Just How Liberal Is California? The Answer Matters to Democrats Everywhere.
description: If progressives can’t win here, it will not bode well for their national efforts.
content: LOS ANGELES — California is awash in money, with so many billions in surplus revenue that the state cannot enact programs fast enough. Democrats hold veto-proof majorities in the Legislature, and Gov. Gavin Newsom has a $25 million campaign war chest to fend off any token opposition in his re-election bid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Traci Braxton, Television Personality and Singer, Dies at 50
description: She was perhaps best known for her appearances on the reality show “Braxton Family Values” with her siblings and their families.
content: Traci Braxton, a television personality and singer, died on Saturday. She was 50.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Pandemic Fears Give Way to a Rush for Bomb Shelters
description: Since Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, European anxiety has shifted from Covid to nuclear annihilation. Bunkers, survival guides and iodine pills are flying off the shelves.
content: BAGNOLO SAN VITO, Italy — Across a footbridge from a busy shopping outlet surrounded by verdant fields in northern Italy, workers in a nondescript warehouse are preparing for a nuclear attack, its radioactive fallout and the end of the world as we know it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: What It Was Like to Work for Russian State Television
description: Until RT America ended abruptly, life as a journalist there was “actually so normal.”
content: For eight years, Lee Camp hosted a weekly show on RT America that aimed to satirize American politics, finding punchlines in subjects like sanctions against Afghanistan and student debt forgiveness. That ended unceremoniously on March 3, a week after Russian airstrikes began in Ukraine, when the Russian-state-funded network suddenly shut down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Cancel Culture in 1832 Sounded Pretty Fierce
description: On Tocqueville and the ostracism that accompanies dissent.
content: One important reason to study history as a social critic or political observer is that it can help you see continuities across time, the ways that certain social and political dynamics recapitulate themselves in various contexts and circumstances. Even as every particular instance of the thing is different, the fact of continuity helps an observer see that the phenomenon does not simply erupt out of the ether, but is the product of larger forces in the society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: The White House approves $200 million in arms and equipment for Ukraine.
description: With the new arms package, which officials say includes antitank and antiaircraft missiles, the Biden administration has authorized $1.2 billion in weapons for Ukraine in the past year.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House has approved an additional $200 million in arms and equipment for Ukraine, administration officials said on Saturday, responding to urgent requests from President Volodymyr Zelensky for more aid to stave off the Russian invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Larkins
title: Florida’s ‘Don’t Say Gay’ Bill Will Hurt Teens Like Me
description: Education made me hate myself less.
content: Last October, I attended a high school Halloween party. A group of guys from my school surrounded me and shouted homophobic slurs. One even threatened me with physical violence. When I broke down crying in class the next day, my teacher comforted me. She told me that she had gone through something similar when she was my age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Pandemic Playlists
description: Sad bangers and other songs that get us through.
content: To get through the pandemic, the writer Hanif Abdurraqib has relied on “sad bangers”: “songs whose lyrics of grief, anxiety, yearning or some other mild or great darkness are washed over with an upbeat tune, or a chorus so infectious that it can weave its way into your brain without your brain taking stock of whatever emotional damage it carries with it.” Bruce Springsteen’s “Hungry Heart” is a sad banger, he writes in The Times Magazine’s annual music issue. So are Robyn’s “Dancing on My Own” and Lil Nas X’s “Lost in the Citadel.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Chaos of War in Ukraine Could Fuel New Covid Surge, Doctors Say
description: War has pushed Covid out of people’s minds while forcing them into crowded and unsanitary conditions that are fertile ground for the coronavirus, polio and other pathogens.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — The last thing on anybody’s mind these days in Ukraine seems to be Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Queen Elizabeth is skipping next week’s Commonwealth Day service.
description: It is still less than a month since the British monarch tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: Buckingham Palace said on Friday that Queen Elizabeth II, who recently recovered from Covid-19, will not attend a Commonwealth Day service at Westminster Abbey next week — in what would have been her first major public engagement in weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China dismisses two mayors and Shanghai closes schools as an outbreak spreads further.
description: BEIJING — Two mayors have been dismissed in northeastern China, and Shanghai has closed its school system and shifted to online instruction, as a coronavirus outbreak in mainland China gathers speed.
content: BEIJING — Two mayors have been dismissed in northeastern China, and Shanghai has closed its school system and shifted to online instruction, as a coronavirus outbreak in mainland China gathers speed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Mask mandates were extended for U.S. transit, but dropped in many other settings: The week in Covid news.
description: In an aggressive step toward normalcy, public school students in New York City returned to mask-optional classrooms on Monday for the first time since the start of the pandemic.
content: In an aggressive step toward normalcy, public school students in New York City returned to mask-optional classrooms on Monday for the first time since the start of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Putin Oligarch Finds Himself Pariah in West’s Playgrounds
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 12, 2022.
content: “The blood of the Ukrainian people is on their hands. They should hang their heads in shame.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: How to Watch the Critics Choice Awards 2022: Date, Time and Streaming
description: It could be a big night for “Belfast” and “West Side Story” — and might finally bring some clarity to the best actress race at the Oscars.
content: If Peter Dinklage’s Cyrano stirred your soul, you’re a fan of Lady Gaga’s over-the-top accent in “House of Gucci,” or you fell hard for “Belfast” cutie Jude Hill, you’ll want to catch the Critics Choice Awards on Sunday night to see if any of them get their due after they were snubbed in the Oscar nominations last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: ‘The Bond King’ Traces the Arc of a Pioneering Investor
description: Bill Gross turned a sleepy market for bond trading into a cutthroat trillion-dollar business. A new book tells the story of his rise and fall.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Shaming Apple and Texting Musk, a Ukraine Minister Uses Novel War Tactics
description: Mykhailo Fedorov, Ukraine’s youngest minister, has turned technology, cryptocurrency and social media into modern weapons of war.
content: After war began last month, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine turned to Mykhailo Fedorov, a vice prime minister, for a key role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike and Adam Liptak
title: Texas Supreme Court Shuts Down Final Challenge to Abortion Law
description: The ruling says state officials have no authority to enforce the law, which empowers private citizens: “We cannot rewrite the statute.”
content: The Texas Supreme Court on Friday effectively shut down a federal challenge to the state’s novel and controversial ban on abortion after about six weeks of pregnancy, closing off what abortion rights advocates said was their last, narrow path to blocking the new law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: American Voters Now View Ukraine as Favorably as France, Germany and Japan
description: In a new  survey, 81 percent of Americans say Ukraine is either friendly or an ally, a figure that rivals or  exceeds that of many longtime U.S. allies.
content: In a new  survey, 81 percent of Americans say Ukraine is either friendly or an ally, a figure that rivals or  exceeds that of many longtime U.S. allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Natalia Yermak, Benjamin Foley, Brent McDonald and Ben Laffin
title: After Days of Uncertainty, a Ukrainian Soldier Is Laid to Rest
description: Senior Lt. Vasyl Vyshyvanyi was killed by Russian forces on March 3, but heavy combat kept the military from evacuating his body. Six days later, he was buried in his home village outside Lviv.
content: Senior Lt. Vasyl Vyshyvanyi was killed by Russian forces on March 3, but heavy combat kept the military from evacuating his body. Six days later, he was buried in his home village outside Lviv.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 12, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 12, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about a collective bargaining agreement between Major League Baseball’s club owners and its players’ union misstated the amount that the M.L.B.’s luxury tax threshold will increase to in 2026. It is $244 million, not $242 million.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Villages in Florida: Shangri-La or Shameful?
description: Readers have strong views about the huge retirement community that offers countless clubs and activities and is largely white and conservative.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
